references: In previous research, many studies have provided proofs of convergence analysis for federated learning. Xiang Li et al.
demonstrated the convergence of the FedAvg algorithm in scenarios with Non-IID data and the possibility of device disconnections. Meanwhile, Tian Li et al.

analyzed the convergence of the FedProx algorithm in cases involving non-convex objective functions, Non-IID data, heterogeneous communication, and computational capabilities among devices. Furthermore, Kang Wei et al.

conducted convergence analysis on the NbAFL algorithm, they proposed to explore the relationship between convergence performance and privacy protection levels. Although these articles performed detailed work on convergence analysis, they primarily used it as a validation tool for algorithm correctness rather than utilizing the results for algorithm optimization.
In past studies, several works have combined differential privacy with federated learning. Kang Wei et al.
introduced the NbAFL algorithm, which first protects privacy in the uplink and then applies noise addition to both the uplink and downlink, achieving privacy protection. Xicong Shen et al.

proposed the PEDPFL algorithm by introducing a regularization term in the objective function, which mitigates the impact of noise introduced by differential privacy on the model. Additionally, Jie Fu et al.

proposed the Adap DP-FL algorithm, which adaptively clips gradients for different clients and rounds by adapting the added noise, optimizing the DPFL algorithm under Non-IID settings. However, the aforementioned works did not consider the impact of
on the convergence speed of the algorithms.
proposed the pFedLA algorithm, which introduced an adaptive hyper-network that applies layer-wise weighting to optimize personalized model aggregation under Non-IID settings. Tian Li et al.
generalized FedAvg by introducing a regularization term in the objective function and incorporating the variable
to control the regularization term and the number of epochs. However, these algorithms only focus on the federated learning and do not consider differential privacy.
To the best of our knowledge, this paper is the first work on convergence analysis and adaptive algorithms for DPFL in a resource-constrained scenario.

references: Each client adds Gaussian noise satisfying differential privacy to the locally trained model can defend against the attacks mentioned in the threat model above. As a result, we only assess each client’s privacy loss from the perspective of a single client. Second, because each client’s locally trained pair of data samples has the same sampling rate and noise factor in each round, each client has the same privacy loss in each round.
